reviews.review_msg: Took this class with her a while back. Her lectures are fine and I personally did not mind her assessments (fair if you go to lectures and pay attention, in my opinion). However, she was quite dismissive and was arguably rude during the couple of interactions I had with her. For these reasons alone I would not take again.
As a professional Mandana knows what she expects. I believe she deserves more out from her job. Just make her a head president of the department because thats Mandana

I noticed that people (I have my suspicions) were writing fake positive reviews for her classes. I took HSCI215 in 2018 and Mandana was extremely rude for no reason. When we were taking the final, a student asked her a question and she literally yelled at him in front of everyone in an auditorium. Exam questions were unfair and marking was unfair

She is sassy but absolutely amazing. Lectures are packed with information but super easy concepts to understand and memorize. Exams are very fair. Group projects were the only downfall with her horrific TA's. Other than that.. she is simply unreal, a gem, not a hard course to do well in if you study.

This is by far the worst class Ive taken at SFU. I would highly recommend avoiding this class with her. You have to attend lecture to fill in the blanks for her notes, which are directly from the WHO. She gives hints about whats on exams but theyre misleading. You have to memorize a bunch of useless stats and tested on 4/100 stats in lecture.

I enjoyed the lectures, but the way she grades exams is just meant to kill your mark. Grading criteria is over specific to the point where if you use 'involvement' instead of 'engagement', you will be marked incorrrect. If you take this course, make sure to memorize the exact words used in the lecture slides.

While Mandana's lectures were well organized and interesting, her marking criteria made this class awful. She did not care to see her students succeed, and the grading of the exams and papers was unfair and used to keep the average low.

Exams consisted of memorizing stats and phrases from her notes word for word. Not sure how thats helpful for future jobs as there is no critical thinking involved. Decent option if you like pure memorization classes I guess.. IMO take the class with someone else, if you want to learn something useful.

Mandana's grade cut-off policy is essentially GPA Cuckoldry. If you get even 0.1 off the next letter grade she will cuck you and not round up, even if you are above 0.5 (72.9 for example). To add to all this, she is condescending when answering questions in lecture and tells you to memorize things for the exam that end up not actually showing up.
Arguably the worst prof at SFU. Exams are way too specific and has such a weird grading scheme. Avoid HSCI 215 with her and take an alternative HSCI lower division course.

One of the WORST PROFESSOR of HSCI215. Her midterms are filled with statistics questions, and she needs exact word to word answer! For example if you say "deliberate" instead of word "intentional", you lose 1 mark. Do yourself a favor, AVOID HER! SHE IS SO RUDE and IRRITATED all the time due to her own issues and throw her ANGER on students.

Reads off the slides during lecture and provides little to no help in preparation for the midterms and final. Exams include obscure statistics and ambiguity in multiple choice, short answer questions are strictly graded, keep in mind, you will have to use her specified terms or be penalized for using a synonymous word that prompts the same meaning

Okay professor, but her marking is SO specific. You'll need to memorize all the slides basically because if you don't use the exact wording she wants, even if your answer is correct, she will tell the TA's to mark it wrong. She gives no disclosures when talking about tough topics, and isn't that approachable.

While firm, she is very clear on what she expects for her exams. If you go to class, take note of the blanks in her slides, what she has highlighted, and the questions she poses during class, you're guaranteed an A. There aren't any surprises with what she expects. If you don't study smart, and just memorize everything, you won't do well.

The material itself is not difficult. The issue is that Mandana doesn't promote any critical thinking in her lectures or tests. Exams are based almost solely on facts and statistics. Lectures are drawn out and uninteresting. Better to skip class and memorize her slides yourself because you won't learn anything additionally from going to lecture.

This class may/may not a GPA booster for you. The final average is only 57%. So make sure you pick generous TA and make an effort in assignment since I feel the test question is somewhat unpredictable(but they are still fair) even though the course content can be pretty straightforward to follow.

Mandana is a great prof. She gave many hints throughout the semester on what would be on the exams, and makes lectures engaging. Can be very humorous and would often end lectures early. I would definitely take another class with her!

A bit physics and biology will help you do better is this courses. Also, not all clues she mentioned in the class will show up on the exams; she does not test you on common sense even though she mentioned in the lecture. Mainly focus on the specific models/mechanisms/steps/flowcharts since these will most likely show up on the exam.

A very genuine and kind professor. super clear during lecture. 1 paper and 1 group project in addition to MT and final which are all super easy and straightforward. She doesnt have a heavy research background and focuses on teaching which she is very good at. Super approachable to ask questions. & BEST DRESSED PROF OF ALL TIME!

Mandana is an O.K. Professor. She is pretty clear on what she expects of you, however I would not take any course she teaches again. Her lectures are just of her reiterating her Powerpoint slides. Her assessments weren't too difficult either. Just study her slides and you're good to go.

Mandana's class is extremely dry and boring. She reads straight from the slides, and it is OBVIOUS she just takes all of her information from the WHO website. I stopped going to lecture and just used the website to fill in slides. She was not good at answering questions and made an interesting topic unbearable. Take it with another prof!

You really need to know the lectures in depth because she asks very specific things from them. Careful how you ask and answer things in class because if you don't answer correctly or the way she likes, she'll definitely give you a bad look. There's a few group presentations. Snobby and seems she only cares about the way she's dresses. Boring prof

She tends to give questions on materials that she didnt explain in depth about during the lecture for the exams She would tell the class to memorize certain parts of the lecture assuming that it will be asked in the exam, but its not. Dont spend time on memorizing the stuff that she asks you to do. Spend time on the details Shes rude and stubborn

Go to lecture to fill in the blanks in her notes, and for better understanding of notes. She tells you to study her lecture notes, the exam is straight from them, yet students still complain about "hard grading" - just study lecture and you're fine. Don't bother with the readings. clear, shows interest in topics, fair exams, but reads off slides

Mandana herself is very nice, and in HSCI 160, she was a fantastic prof. However; I found HSCI 215 quite a broad class, that needs to be revised, as all of her material comes from WHO Reports. Tests are a bit tricky, as well.
She is nice,approachable ,organize... her tests are very fair.. and yeaa do the work get a decent grade

Lectures were incredibly boring and even long. And the prof will read every single words on the slides. There's no point to go to lectures but you will have to go to fill in the blanks on the slides. Tests doesn't seem tough but she is very picky when grading. I recommend you to avoid her if possible. Don't take a course with her. Please.

Remember every detail. I do mean EVERY DETAIL. This course is hardcore memorization and if you are not ready to put exactly what's in the slides onto the test paper, you won't do well at all. Professor is arrogant and has a way of patronizing students.

I found explanations to questions more confusing than clarifying. Sometimes she says contradictions to true. Eg. advertised that gym is free but students pay approx..$60 per term.Exams too much memo.Introducing Kin&physic terms  that are not studied in depth so memorizing terms seems useless but imp. on exam!1/2 course material useful info 1/2 not

This class is purely memorization of her lecture slides. And when I say memorization.. it's literally you gotta know everything WORD for WORD.. if not you won't get the mark. She stresses broad, key concepts in lecture, yet the exams ask for the most minuscule details.

Thought that she was going to make my semester living hell based on the ratings I read, but she turned out to be one of my favourite profs. Midterms are straightforward, based on lecture slides (no text), one 3-hr LEC a week with TUT, TUT quizzes are easy. If you miss class, can easily get someone's notes. She doesn't try to screw you over.
Mandana so fab.

I felt her expertise was being stretched a bit thin and she emphasized memorization too much in her tests, but overall I enjoyed the class and learned a lot. She is a good lecturer and very approachable outside of class time.

Way too hard for a 200 level! She makes the content much much harder than it should have been. She talks about things in terms of physics when it's a hsci class. On top of that you had to literally write your answers word for word to get full marks. She asked for specific numbers and you had to memorize charts... TAKE ANY OTHER HSCI 200 CLASS.

THE WORST CLASS EVER! I THINK THIS'S A KINDERGARDEN CLASS NOT UNIVERSITY LEVEL. SHE ASKS U TO MEMORIZE EVERY SINGLE THING. RIDICULOUS! percentages & unnecessary #s must be all memorized. I'm A student but I got C-!! she copies info from websites &her citation linksdontwork. Yes, she cites some of them someavoid this prof by all means THE WORST

The professor is asking students to memorize information word by word that is widely available online. This course is not challenging,unfortunately the teacher marks for memorization word by word. At the end of the class you havent learned anything that is not yet available on WHO. The WORST CLASS  at SFU and the teacher is highly unapproachable!!!

If you are good at memorization this course is super easy. As long as you study and read the notes COMPLETELY over and over you are guaranteed an A since all the stuff on the exam is on the notes. This course had no textbooks too so it was great!
marking is not fair anymore. really picky, lot of memorization...
Very specific course if you don't memorize the exact words on the slides don't expect a mark.

Don't take this class unless you're willing to memorize every single detail on every slide. Her tests are specific and you only get the mark if you put the EXACT word down sometimes... This class didn't even really cover injury and disability, went WAY too broad beyond its purpose.

Well, her lectures are mandatory pretty much because her slides are fill-in-the-blank. However, she adds absolutely nothing to her powerpoint presentations, and her English grammar is atrocious. She also says the word 'um' in just about every sentence, which I find  highly distracting. BUT, this is a very easy 3 credits provided you attend class.

She is awful as a professor! Avoid her if you can. Had weekly quizes and she would ask very specific information. Her multiple choices were aim to confuse students. Class average was 68% which is really low for a second year Health Science course. Exams were unfair. Taking this course felt like 2 course load.

She often makes fun of students who put their hands up in class, her lectures are useless (all the slides are online), her exams are far too specific and unfairly marked, and the course didn't even teach much of what it was supposed to. No textbook, which is okay, but only take this course if you're willing to memorize everything on the slides.

He is not a good teaching assistant, most students in his tutorial wrote in their TA feedback to never hire him again and some reached out to the faculty dean. He is impatient when you go to his office hours and he knows nothing about the course material. Unclear instructions and marking. Never be in his tutorial - you will definitely regret it.
